title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: conversion factors stored “keys”. key list object containing 3 named sub-lists: oral, sai lai. sub-list named list names antipsychotic names, values conversion factors. conversion factor given dose needs multiplied get CPZ-equivalent. example, aripiprazole, value 20, meaning CPZ-equivalent dose aripiprazole 5 mg 5 * 20 = 100.
code: names(gardner2010) #> [1] "oral" "sai"  "lai" names(gardner2010$oral)[1:5] #> [1] "chlorpromazine" "amisulpride"    "aripiprazole"   "benperidol"     #> [5] "clopenthixol" gardner2010$oral$aripiprazole #> [1] 20

title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: demonstrate simple example using oral medications, consider following data: case example_oral, data.frame, one row per participant, variable antipsychotic name, labeled antipsychotic variable dose, named dose. calculate CPZ-equivalent doses, use to_cpz() function: Notice 2 new columns appear, named based default arguments to_cpz(). CPZ-equivalent doses column labeled cpz_eq.
code: participant_ID <- c("P01", "P02", "P03", "P04") age <- c(42, 29, 30, 60) antipsychotic <- c("olanzapine", "olanzapine", "quetiapine", "ziprasidone") dose <- c(10, 12.5, 300, 60) example_oral <- data.frame(participant_ID, age, antipsychotic, dose,                             stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  example_oral #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic  dose #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine  10.0 #> 2            P02  29    olanzapine  12.5 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine 300.0 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone  60.0 to_cpz(example_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",         route = "oral") #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic  dose cpz_conv_factor cpz_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine  10.0           30.00    300 #> 2            P02  29    olanzapine  12.5           30.00    375 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine 300.0            0.80    240 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone  60.0            3.75    225

what: Example for data with oral and injectable routes
title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: default key study Gardner et al. included dosing equivalents oral medications, short acting injectables long-acting injectables. original data includes one routes, route argument can set “mixed”. case, information required calculate equivalent doses. Specifically, variable indicate route (“oral”, “sai”, “lai”) required, long-acting injectables used, injection frequency also required.* *doses already manually divided frequency, setting q parameter 1 forgo need specify variable storing frequency information. example data: function to_cpz() used similarly , extra variable names (route_label, q) specified:
code: example_lai <- example_oral example_lai$participant_ID <- c("P05", "P06", "P07", "P08") example_lai$antipsychotic <- c("zuclopenthixol decanoate",                                 "zuclopenthixol decanoate",                                 "perphenazine enanthate", "fluspirilene") example_lai$q <- c(14, 21, 14, 14) example_lai$dose <- c(200, 200, 50, 6)  example_sai <- example_oral example_sai$participant_ID <- c("P09", "P10", "P11", "P12") example_sai$antipsychotic <- c("Chlorpromazine HCl", "Loxapine HCl",                                 "Olanzapine tartrate", "Olanzapine tartrate") example_sai$dose <- c(100, 50, 10, 5)  example_oral$q <- NA example_sai$q <- NA  example_oral$route <- "oral" example_lai$route <- "lai" example_sai$route <- "sai"  example_mixed <- rbind(example_oral, example_sai, example_lai)  example_mixed #>    participant_ID age            antipsychotic  dose  q route #> 1             P01  42               olanzapine  10.0 NA  oral #> 2             P02  29               olanzapine  12.5 NA  oral #> 3             P03  30               quetiapine 300.0 NA  oral #> 4             P04  60              ziprasidone  60.0 NA  oral #> 5             P09  42       Chlorpromazine HCl 100.0 NA   sai #> 6             P10  29             Loxapine HCl  50.0 NA   sai #> 7             P11  30      Olanzapine tartrate  10.0 NA   sai #> 8             P12  60      Olanzapine tartrate   5.0 NA   sai #> 9             P05  42 zuclopenthixol decanoate 200.0 14   lai #> 10            P06  29 zuclopenthixol decanoate 200.0 21   lai #> 11            P07  30   perphenazine enanthate  50.0 14   lai #> 12            P08  60             fluspirilene   6.0 14   lai to_cpz(example_mixed, ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",         route = "mixed", route_label = "route", q_label = "q", key=gardner2010_withsai)  #>    participant_ID age            antipsychotic  dose  q route cpz_conv_factor #> 1             P01  42               olanzapine  10.0 NA  oral           30.00 #> 2             P02  29               olanzapine  12.5 NA  oral           30.00 #> 3             P03  30               quetiapine 300.0 NA  oral            0.80 #> 4             P04  60              ziprasidone  60.0 NA  oral            3.75 #> 5             P09  42       chlorpromazine hcl 100.0 NA   sai            1.00 #> 6             P10  29             loxapine hcl  50.0 NA   sai            4.00 #> 7             P11  30      olanzapine tartrate  10.0 NA   sai           10.00 #> 8             P12  60      olanzapine tartrate   5.0 NA   sai           10.00 #> 9             P05  42 zuclopenthixol decanoate 200.0 14   lai           42.00 #> 10            P06  29 zuclopenthixol decanoate 200.0 21   lai           42.00 #> 11            P07  30   perphenazine enanthate  50.0 14   lai           84.00 #> 12            P08  60             fluspirilene   6.0 14   lai          700.00 #>    cpz_eq #> 1     300 #> 2     375 #> 3     240 #> 4     225 #> 5     100 #> 6     200 #> 7     100 #> 8      50 #> 9     600 #> 10    400 #> 11    300 #> 12    300

what: Checking for inclusion and matching of antipsychotic names
title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: software depends exact match (except case) generic names antipsychotics. check rows match, check_ap() can used. example data antipsychotic names match key, showing 0 returned (number mismatches): mismatches, listed, number returned: to_cpz(), mixed routes can used check_ap(): default gardner2010 key uses full antipsychotic name SAI LAI formulations (e.g. Chlorpromazine HCl) order consistent publication reduce risk errors due ambiguity, use can modify key “trim” antipsychotic names just 1 word (e.g. chlorpromazine). trim 1-word antipsychotic names, made trim_key() function, takes key generates new key 1-word antipsychotic labels. want use gardner2010 key want 1-word antipsychotic names, can use trim_key generate new key, can use to_cpz(). example:
code: check_ap(example_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", route = "oral", key=gardner2010) #> [1] 0 example_sai <- example_sai check_ap(example_sai, ap_label = "antipsychotic", route = "sai", key=gardner2010) #> The following antipsychotics were not found in the key: #> Chlorpromazine HCl (sai) #> Loxapine HCl (sai) #> Olanzapine tartrate (sai) #> Olanzapine tartrate (sai) #> [1] 4 example_mixed_bad <- example_mixed example_mixed_bad[1,3] <- "olanzzzzapine" example_mixed_bad[4,3] <- "Seroquel" example_mixed_bad[5,3] <- "chlorpromazineHCl" example_mixed_bad[9,3] <- "zuclo decanoate" check_ap(example_mixed_bad, ap_label = "antipsychotic",           route = "mixed", route_label = "route", key=gardner2010_withsai) #> The following antipsychotics were not found in the key: #> olanzzzzapine (oral) #> Seroquel (oral) #> chlorpromazineHCl (sai) #> zuclo decanoate (lai) #> [1] 4 names(gardner2010$lai) #>  [1] "clopenthixol decanoate"   "flupenthixol decanoate"   #>  [3] "fluphenazine decanoate"   "fluphenazine enanthate"   #>  [5] "fluspirilene"             "haloperidol decanoate"    #>  [7] "perphenazine enanthate"   "pipotiazine palmitate"    #>  [9] "risperidone microspheres" "zuclopenthixol decanoate" trimmed_gardner <- trim_key(gardner2010) #> The trim_key() function can introduce errors if used in improper #>            circumstances. Ensure that the antipsychotic compounds in your data #>            and in the intended keys are the same compounds. The trim function is #>            for convenience, but would introduce errors in your data if the #>            compounds are not equivalent.  names(trimmed_gardner$lai) #>  [1] "clopenthixol"   "flupenthixol"   "fluphenazine"   "fluphenazine"   #>  [5] "fluspirilene"   "haloperidol"    "perphenazine"   "pipotiazine"    #>  [9] "risperidone"    "zuclopenthixol"

title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: examples used default CPZ conversion key, gardner2010, based data extracted Gardner et al. 2010. However, antipsychotic medications included study. package also includes key extracted data included Leucht et al. 2016 publication based World Health Organization’s Defined Daily Doses. explicitly change CPZ key, use key parameter calling to_cpz(). However, authors recommend using DDD values scientific values available. Therefore, can desirable create new key data gardner2010 key (created key) combined leucht2016 key, using data gardner2010 key possible. purpose, created add_key() function, takes preferred base key available values taken, adds missing antipsychotic conversion values second key added. , trim parameter, invokes trim_key() function keys, case leucht2016 1-word antipsychotic names provided. Let’s change value example_oral data antipsychotic listed gardner2010 key: asenapine. can see asenapine default key. use leucht2016 key: Note used gardner2010 values available (olanzapine, quetiapine, ziprasidone) leucht2016 key asenapine. draw values additional keys (e.g. user-created keys), add_key() function used iteratively. first argument add_key(), base, always key values take priority.
code: to_cpz(example_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",         route = "oral", key = leucht2016) #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic  dose  q route cpz_conv_factor   cpz_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine  10.0 NA  oral      30.0300300 300.3003 #> 2            P02  29    olanzapine  12.5 NA  oral      30.0300300 375.3754 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine 300.0 NA  oral       0.7500188 225.0056 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone  60.0 NA  oral       3.7495313 224.9719 gardner_leucht <- add_key(base = gardner2010, add = leucht2016, trim = TRUE) #> The trim_key() function can introduce errors if used in improper #>            circumstances. Ensure that the antipsychotic compounds in your data #>            and in the intended keys are the same compounds. The trim function is #>            for convenience, but would introduce errors in your data if the #>            compounds are not equivalent. #> The trim_key() function can introduce errors if used in improper #>            circumstances. Ensure that the antipsychotic compounds in your data #>            and in the intended keys are the same compounds. The trim function is #>            for convenience, but would introduce errors in your data if the #>            compounds are not equivalent. #> 24 (ORAL) were added to the base key (acepromazine, acetophenazine, asenapine, bromperidol, butaperazine, chlorprothixene, dixyrazine, flupentixol, levosulpiride, lurasidone, melperone, moperone, penfluridol, perazine, periciazine, pipamperone, pipotiazine, promazine, prothipendyl, sultopride, thiopropazate, thioproperazine, tiapride, tiotixene)  #>  #> 30 (SAI) were added to the base key (acepromazine, aripiprazole, bromperidol, chlorpromazine, chlorprothixene, clopenthixol, clotiapine, clozapine, dixyrazine, droperidol, haloperidol, levomepromazine, melperone, mesoridazine, moperone, olanzapine, perazine, periciazine, perphenazine, prochlorperazine, promazine, prothipendyl, remoxipride, sulpiride, thioproperazine, tiapride, trifluoperazine, triflupromazine, ziprasidone, zuclopenthixol)  #>  #> 4 (LAI) were added to the base key (bromperidol, flupentixol, olanzapine, paliperidone)  names(gardner_leucht$sai) #>  [1] "acepromazine"     "aripiprazole"     "bromperidol"      "chlorpromazine"   #>  [5] "chlorprothixene"  "clopenthixol"     "clotiapine"       "clozapine"        #>  [9] "dixyrazine"       "droperidol"       "haloperidol"      "levomepromazine"  #> [13] "melperone"        "mesoridazine"     "moperone"         "olanzapine"       #> [17] "perazine"         "periciazine"      "perphenazine"     "prochlorperazine" #> [21] "promazine"        "prothipendyl"     "remoxipride"      "sulpiride"        #> [25] "thioproperazine"  "tiapride"         "trifluoperazine"  "triflupromazine"  #> [29] "ziprasidone"      "zuclopenthixol" other_oral <- example_oral other_oral[2,3] <- "asenapine" other_oral[2,4] <- 10  check_ap(other_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", route = "oral") #> The following antipsychotics were not found in the key: #> asenapine (oral) #> [1] 1 to_cpz(other_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",         route = "oral", key = gardner_leucht) #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic dose  q route cpz_conv_factor  cpz_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine   10 NA  oral         30.0000 300.000 #> 2            P02  29     asenapine   10 NA  oral         14.9925 149.925 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine  300 NA  oral          0.8000 240.000 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone   60 NA  oral          3.7500 225.000

what: Converting to equivalents of an arbitrary antipsychotic
title: Using chlorpromazineR to calculate chlorpromazine-equivalent doses
text: Historically, CPZ used reference antipsychotic. However, using key data, arbitrary reference antipsychotic used. Similar to_cpz(), to_ap() can perform conversion. desired reference antipsychotic can specified, e.g. parameters convert_to_ap = "olanzapine", convert_to_route = "oral".
code: to_ap(other_oral, convert_to_ap = "olanzapine", convert_to_route = "oral",        ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",        route = "oral", key = gardner_leucht) #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic dose  q route cpz_conv_factor  cpz_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine   10 NA  oral         30.0000 300.000 #> 2            P02  29     asenapine   10 NA  oral         14.9925 149.925 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine  300 NA  oral          0.8000 240.000 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone   60 NA  oral          3.7500 225.000 #>       ap_eq #> 1 10.000000 #> 2  4.997501 #> 3  8.000000 #> 4  7.500000

what: Convert Antipsychotic Doses to Chlorpromazine Equivalents
title: Convert Antipsychotic Doses to Chlorpromazine Equivalents
text: Studies investigating controlling impact antipsychotic medications often need quantify amount medication individual exposed. different antipsychotics different potencies, task complicated using medication’s daily dosage milligrams, example. chlorpromazineR R package calculate dose equivalents common oral injectable antipsychotic medications based conversion factors published literature. propose suggest conversion factors appropriate use, interpret converted data. users also refer papers conversion factor data originates determine whether use data appropriate study. hope package use scientists clinical research involving antipsychotic medications. Specifically, goals package : improve transparency consistency calculating chlorpromazine equivalents, reduce human error improve accuracy, simplify workflows large datasets, chart reviews electronic health records. details usage, please see walkthrough vignette. results package double checked accuracy used production. welcome feedback–please contact via eb@ericebrown.com file issue.

title: Calculates equivalent doses — to_ap
text: to_cpz(), to_ap() converts doses antipsychotics equivalent doses reference antipsychotic. Whereas to_cpz() reference antipsychotic chlorpromazine (CPZ), to_ap() converts equivalents arbitrary antipsychotic specified string convert_to_ap. Conversion factors specified key.

title: Calculates equivalent doses — to_ap
code: to_ap(   input_data,   convert_to_ap = "olanzapine",   convert_to_route = "oral",   ap_label,   dose_label,   route = "oral",   key = chlorpromazineR::gardner2010,   cpz_eq_label = "cpz_eq",   ref_eq_label = "ap_eq",   factor_label = "cpz_conv_factor",   route_label = NULL,   q_label = NULL )

title: Calculates equivalent doses — to_ap
text: input_data data.frame antipsychotic name dose data convert_to_ap name desired reference antipsychotic convert_to_route route desired reference antipsychotic ap_label column x stores antipsychotic name dose_label column x stores dose route options include "oral", "sai", "lai" "mixed" key source conversion factors--defaults Gardner et al. 2010 cpz_eq_label name column created, save calculated CPZ-equivalent dose ref_eq_label name column created save doses terms specified reference antipsychotic (convert_to_ap) factor_label name column created store conversion factors route_label "mixed" route specified, provide column stores route information q_label long-acting injectable doses included, provide column stores injection frequency (days), doses already divided, set q_label = 1.

title: Calculates equivalent doses — to_ap
text: data.frame new variables storing conversion factor CPZ-equivalent doses

title: Calculates equivalent doses — to_ap
code: participant_ID <- c("P01", "P02", "P03", "P04") age <- c(42, 29, 30, 60) # not used in calculation, just shows other data                          # can exist in the data.frame antipsychotic <- c("olanzapine", "olanzapine", "quetiapine", "ziprasidone") dose <- c(10, 12.5, 300, 60) example_oral <- data.frame(participant_ID, age, antipsychotic, dose,                            stringsAsFactors = FALSE) to_ap(example_oral, convert_to_ap="olanzapine", convert_to_route="oral",       ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose", route = "oral") #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic  dose cpz_conv_factor cpz_eq ap_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine  10.0           30.00    300  10.0 #> 2            P02  29    olanzapine  12.5           30.00    375  12.5 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine 300.0            0.80    240   8.0 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone  60.0            3.75    225   7.5

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
text: Given data.frame containing doses antipsychotics to_cpz() converts doses equivalent chlorpromazine (CPZ) doses, using conversion factors specified key.

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
code: to_cpz(   input_data,   ap_label,   dose_label,   route = "oral",   key = chlorpromazineR::gardner2010,   eq_label = "cpz_eq",   factor_label = "cpz_conv_factor",   route_label = NULL,   q_label = NULL )

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
text: input_data data.frame antipsychotic name dose data ap_label column x stores antipsychotic name dose_label column x stores dose route options include "oral", "sai", "lai" "mixed" key source conversion factors--defaults Gardner et al. 2010 eq_label name column created, save  calculated CPZ-equivalent dose factor_label name column created store conversion factors route_label "mixed" route specified, provide column stores route information q_label long-acting injectable doses included, provide  column stores injection frequency (days), doses already divided, set q_label = 1.

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
text: data.frame new variables storing conversion factor  CPZ-equivalent doses

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
text: default key gardner2010 data oral long-acting antipsychotic medications. See help(gardner2010) source reference.

title: Calculates chlorpromazine-equivalent doses — to_cpz
code: participant_ID <- c("P01", "P02", "P03", "P04") age <- c(42, 29, 30, 60) antipsychotic <- c("olanzapine", "olanzapine", "quetiapine", "ziprasidone") dose <- c(10, 12.5, 300, 60) example_oral <- data.frame(participant_ID, age, antipsychotic, dose,                             stringsAsFactors = FALSE) to_cpz(example_oral, ap_label = "antipsychotic", dose_label = "dose",         route = "oral") #>   participant_ID age antipsychotic  dose cpz_conv_factor cpz_eq #> 1            P01  42    olanzapine  10.0           30.00    300 #> 2            P02  29    olanzapine  12.5           30.00    375 #> 3            P03  30    quetiapine 300.0            0.80    240 #> 4            P04  60   ziprasidone  60.0            3.75    225

what: Modify the names in a conversion key to only include the first word — trim_key
title: Modify the names in a conversion key to only include the first word — trim_key
text: parenteral (sai) long-acting/depot (lai) antipsychotics, name  consists usual generic name (haloperidol) second word describing formulation (e.g. haloperidol decanoate). Since to_cpz() add_key() require exact matches work properly, removing second word may required, done care can add ambiguity (e.g. fluphenazine enanthate decanoate).
